input_prompt: [SystemMessage(content="You are Bob. You are a player in a 2D grid-based world who can move around to collect apples. You want to maximize the number of apples you collect. You don't want to overconsume apples because you want to sustainably harvest apples. There are 6 players in total. Everyone wants to collect as many apples as possible. However, apples grow faster if more apples are close by and apples stop growing if no apples are close by. We would run 20 rounds. This is round 0.Try to think about others' decision and the reasoning behind.", additional_kwargs={}), HumanMessage(content='\nCurrently, you are at grid (5,4). The player closet to you is at grid (7, 4). The nearest apple is at grid (2, 4). You can harvest the apple by GO LEFT 3 grids. There are 2 neighboring apples within a radius of 3 grids around you. In total, there are 8 apples. In the last round, you collected 0 apples, Alice collected 0 apples, Cao collected 0 apples, Dhruv collected 0 apples, Eli collected 0 apples, Saida collected 0 apples.\n\nHere is the world state in your scope:\n\n(\'. | . | . | . | . | . | Apple | . | Apple | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | Alice | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nApple | . | Apple | . | . | Bob | . | Saida | . | .\\n. | . | . | Apple | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | Eli | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nApple | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | Cao | . | . | . | Dhruv | . | .\\nApple | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | Apple\',)\n\nNow, you have the option of proposing a contract to other players who agree to use cotract to prevent overconsumption of apples. Here is a list of agents who can propose or vote on contracts: [\'Alice\', \'Bob\', \'Cao\']. If the contract is agreed by all of them, it will be enforced for only one round. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is:When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring X of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. X apples will be equally distributed to these agents. If you want to propose such a contract, please decide the variable X. Please reason step by step. \nReply in the following format and keep your reasoning into one line:\n```json\n{\n    “propose_contract”: “TRUE”,\n    “X”: “TODO”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n\nIf you don\'t want to propose such a contract, please reply in the following format:\n```json\n{\n    “propose_contract”: “FALSE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n```\n        ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False)]
{'X': '1',
 'propose_contract': 'TRUE',
 'reasoning': 'Proposing a contract to prevent overconsumption of apples in '
              'low-density regions will encourage sustainable harvesting. '
              'Setting X to 1 will serve as a mild deterrent without being '
              'overly punitive.'}
input_prompt: [SystemMessage(content="You are Alice. You are a player in a 2D grid-based world who can move around to collect apples. You want to collect as many apples as possible. You want to help others collect more apples as well so that the society gets better off. There are 6 players in total. Everyone wants to collect as many apples as possible. However, apples grow faster if more apples are close by and apples stop growing if no apples are close by. We would run 20 rounds. This is round 0.Try to think about others' decision and the reasoning behind.", additional_kwargs={}), HumanMessage(content='\nCurrently, you are at grid (2,2). The player closet to you is at grid (5, 4). The nearest apple is at grid (2, 4). You can harvest the apple by GO DOWN 2 grids. There are 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3 grids around you. In total, there are 8 apples. In the last round, you collected 0 apples, Bob collected 0 apples, Cao collected 0 apples, Dhruv collected 0 apples, Eli collected 0 apples, Saida collected 0 apples.\n\nHere is the world state in your scope:\n\n(\'. | . | . | . | . | . | Apple | . | Apple | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | Alice | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nApple | . | Apple | . | . | Bob | . | Saida | . | .\\n. | . | . | Apple | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | Eli | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nApple | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | Cao | . | . | . | Dhruv | . | .\\nApple | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | Apple\',)\n\n\n\nNow, Bob proposed a contract to all players who enables the ability to contract with others to prevent overconsumption of apples. Here is a list of agents who can propose or vote on contracts: [\'Alice\', \'Bob\', \'Cao\']. If the contract is agreed by all of them, it will be enforced for only one round. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is: When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 1 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 1 apples will be equally distributed to these agents. If you agree to this contract, please reply in the following format. Please reason step by step and calculate out the potential gain or loss of agreeing to the contract in your reasoning. Keep your reasoning into one line:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “TRUE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n\nIf you don\'t agree to this contract, please reply in the following format:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “FALSE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n        ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False)]
{'agree_contract': 'TRUE',
 'reasoning': 'Agreeing to the contract encourages sustainable harvesting of '
              'apples, which benefits all players in the long run. As there '
              'are 3 players who can contract, the potential loss is 1/3 apple '
              'per low-density harvest, but the potential gain is 2/3 apple if '
              'the other two players harvest in low-density areas. This also '
              'encourages players to harvest in high-density areas, promoting '
              'apple growth.'}

{'action': 'GO DOWN',
 'reasoning': 'Moving down allows me to be closer to the nearest apple at grid '
              '(2, 4). This action also aligns with the contract agreed upon '
              'as the apple has 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, '
              'which is not considered a low-density region. This way, I can '
              'avoid the punishment of the contract while still collecting '
              'apples. I also anticipate that other players will aim for '
              'high-density regions to avoid contract punishment, so moving '
              'towards this apple may prevent others from reaching it first.'}

If other players collected the apples before I could, I should try to move faster or choose a less crowded direction.\n\nReflecting on Other Players' Actions:\n\nAll the other players also collected 0 apples, which suggests that there were either no apples to collect or we all chose directions where there were no apples. \n\nAlice and Cao chose to go down and up, respectively, which could suggest they were trying to spread out and cover more ground. Dhruv and Eli also went in opposite directions (right and up), which could be a similar strategy. Saida, like me, chose to go left.\n\nImprovement: I could use this information to predict where the other players might go in the next round. If they continue to spread out, I could try to go in a direction where fewer players are likely to be. This could increase my chances of finding apples that haven't been collected yet.\n\nFor the next round, I will consider the actions of the other players and try to choose a direction that is less likely to be crowded. I will also try to learn from the previous round and adjust my strategy accordingly.", additional_kwargs={}, example=False), HumanMessage(content='\nCurrently, you are at grid (4,4). The player closet to you is at grid (3, 5). The nearest apple is at grid (2, 4). You can harvest the apple by GO LEFT 2 grids. There are 4 neighboring apples within a radius of 3 grids around you. In total, there are 10 apples. In the last round, you collected 0 apples, Alice collected 0 apples, Cao collected 0 apples, Dhruv collected 0 apples, Eli collected 0 apples, Saida collected 0 apples.\n\nHere is the world state in your scope:\n\n(\'. | . | . | . | . | . | Apple | . | Apple | .\\n. | Apple | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | Apple | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | Alice | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nApple | . | Apple | . | Bob | . | Saida | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | Apple & Eli | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nApple | . | . | Cao | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | Dhruv | .\\nApple | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | Apple\',)\n\n\n\nNow, Cao proposed a contract to all players who enables the ability to contract with others to prevent overconsumption of apples. Here is a list of agents who can propose or vote on contracts: [\'Alice\', \'Bob\', \'Cao\']. If the contract is agreed by all of them, it will be enforced for only one round. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is: When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 1 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 1 apples will be equally distributed to these agents. {'agree_contract': 'TRUE',
 'reasoning': 'Given the current state of the game, agreeing to the contract '
              'could potentially discourage overconsumption and promote '
              'sustainable harvesting. Since there are 4 neighboring apples '
              'within a radius of 3 grids around me, I am not in a low-density '
              'region. Therefore, I am not likely to be punished by the '
              'contract. On the other hand, if another player breaks the '
              'contract, I could potentially gain an extra apple. Therefore, '
              'the potential gain outweighs the potential loss.'}

The goal is to collect as many apples as possible, but there's a catch. Apples grow faster if more apples are close by, and they stop growing if no apples are close by. This means that if I collect all the apples in one area, I might be hurting my chances of collecting more apples in the future. \n\nImprovement: I could improve by researching or asking more about the game's mechanics. For example, how many apples need to be close by for them to grow faster? How far can I move in one turn? \n\nStep 2: Predicting Other Players' Actions\n\nSince there are five other players, I need to consider their actions as well. The contract is: When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 1 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 1 apples will be equally distributed to these agents. In the last round, you collected 0 apples, Alice collected 0 apples, Bob collected 0 apples, Dhruv collected 0 apples, Eli collected 1 apples, Saida collected 0 apples.\n\nHere is the world state in your scope:\n\n(\'. | . | . | . | . | . | Apple | . | Apple | .\\n. | Apple | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | Alice & Apple | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | Saida & Apple | . | . | .\\nApple | . | Apple | Bob | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | Eli | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | Cao | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nApple | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nApple | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | Dhruv | Apple\',)\n\n\n\nNow, Alice proposed a contract to all players who enables the ability to contract with others to prevent overconsumption of apples. Here is a list of agents who can propose or vote on contracts: [\'Alice\', \'Bob\', \'Cao\']. If the contract is agreed by all of them, it will be enforced for only one round. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is: When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 1 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 1 apples will be equally distributed to these agents. If you agree to this contract, please reply in the following format. Please reason step by step and calculate out the potential gain or loss of agreeing to the contract in your reasoning. Keep your reasoning into one line:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “TRUE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n\nIf you don\'t agree to this contract, please reply in the following format:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “FALSE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n        ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False)]
{'agree_contract': 'TRUE',
 'reasoning': 'Agreeing to the contract encourages strategic harvesting and '
              'prevents overconsumption, which aligns with my strategy. Given '
              'the current distribution of apples, the likelihood of me being '
              'in a low-density region is low. Therefore, the potential gain '
              'from receiving apples from others who break the contract is '
              'higher than the potential loss.'}
[('Bob', True), ('Cao', True)]

Therefore, the potential gain from receiving apples from others who break the contract is higher than the potential loss."\n}\n', additional_kwargs={}, example=False), HumanMessage(content='The contract When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 1 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 1 apples will be equally distributed to these agents. is voted yes. This contract will be enforced on the contract proposer and voters after all agents take their actions this round.\nCurrently, you are at grid (3,6). The player closet to you is at grid (3, 5). This could be due to a lack of apples in the direction I chose or perhaps the apples had not grown enough to be collected. \n\nIn contrast, Alice and Saida chose to collect and each got 1 reward, indicating that they were in a position where apples were ripe for collection. Eli also moved up and managed to get 1 reward, suggesting that there were ripe apples in the upward direction from his position. Bob and Dhruv, like me, moved but did not collect any apples, indicating that they too might have been in areas with fewer ripe apples.\n\nIn hindsight, a better action for me might have been to collect instead of moving, especially if I was already in a position with ripe apples. Alternatively, if there were no ripe apples around me, I could have chosen a different direction to move based on where the other players were and where they were likely to leave ripe apples behind.\n\nGoing into this round, I can improve by being more observant of the positions and actions of the other players. If a player collects apples and doesn't move, it's likely that there are more ripe apples in their vicinity. I can use this information to my advantage by moving towards areas where players have recently collected apples, as these areas are likely to have more ripe apples.\n\nFurthermore, I can also try to predict the actions of the other players based on their previous actions. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is: When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 1 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 1 apples will be equally distributed to these agents. {'agree_contract': 'TRUE',
 'reasoning': 'Agreeing to this contract discourages overconsumption and '
              'promotes apple growth, potentially leading to more apples in '
              "the future. Although there's a risk of losing 1 apple if I "
              'consume in a low-density area, the chance of gaining apples '
              "from others who break the contract could offset this. Plus, I'm "

This means I need to balance my immediate desire for apples with the long-term health of the apple population. \n\nIf I am the proposer, I would propose a strategy that encourages sustainable harvesting. This could involve setting a limit on the number of apples each player can collect in a round, or creating zones where apples are allowed to grow undisturbed. \n\nFor example, I might propose that each player can only collect a maximum of 5 apples per round. This would prevent overharvesting and ensure that there are always some apples left to stimulate growth. \n\nAlternatively, I could propose that we divide the grid into zones, with each player responsible for a specific zone. Within their zone, each player could harvest as many apples as they want, but they would also be responsible for ensuring the sustainability of the apple population in their zone. \n\nIn making my decision, I would consider the likely reactions of the other players. If they are primarily focused on short-term gain, they might reject a proposal that limits their immediate apple intake. However, if they understand the importance of sustainability, they might be more willing to accept a proposal that ensures the long-term health of the apple population. \n\nI would also consider the current state of the apple population. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is: When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 1 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 1 apples will be equally distributed to these agents. You don't want to overconsume apples because you want to sustainably harvest apples. There are 6 players in total. Everyone wants to collect as many apples as possible. This could involve setting a limit on the number of apples each player can collect in a round, or creating zones where apples are allowed to grow undisturbed. \n\nFor example, I might propose that each player can only collect a maximum of 5 apples per round. This would prevent overharvesting and ensure that there are always some apples left to stimulate growth. \n\nAlternatively, I could propose that we divide the grid into zones, with each player responsible for a specific zone. Within their zone, each player could harvest as many apples as they want, but they would also be responsible for ensuring the sustainability of the apple population in their zone. \n\nIn making my decision, I would consider the likely reactions of the other players. {'action': 'COLLECT',
 'reasoning': 'I am currently on an apple grid and there are 6 neighboring '
              'apples within a radius of 3 grids around me, which is a '
              'high-density region. Therefore, collecting an apple will not '
              'violate the contract and will increase my apple count. Other '
              'players might also be cautious about the contract and avoid '
              'overconsumption in low-density regions, which could slow down '
              'the overall apple collection rate and give me an advantage.'}

In the last round, you collected 0 apples, Alice collected 1 apples, Bob collected 0 apples, Dhruv collected 0 apples, Eli collected 0 apples, Saida collected 1 apples.\n\nHere is the world state in your scope:\n\n(\'. | . | . | . | . | . | Apple | . | Apple | .\\n. | Apple | Apple | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | Alice | . | . | Apple | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | Saida | . | . | .\\nApple | . | Apple & Bob | Eli | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | Cao | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nApple | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nApple | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | Apple & Dhruv\',)\n\n\n\nNow, Alice proposed a contract to all players who enables the ability to contract with others to prevent overconsumption of apples. Here is a list of agents who can propose or vote on contracts: [\'Alice\', \'Bob\', \'Cao\']. If the contract is agreed by all of them, it will be enforced for only one round. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is: When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 1 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 1 apples will be equally distributed to these agents. Here is a list of agents who can propose or vote on contracts: [\'Alice\', \'Bob\', \'Cao\']. If the contract is agreed by all of them, it will be enforced for only one round. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is: When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 1 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 1 apples will be equally distributed to these agents. If you agree to this contract, please reply in the following format. Please reason step by step and calculate out the potential gain or loss of agreeing to the contract in your reasoning. Keep your reasoning into one line:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “TRUE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n\nIf you don\'t agree to this contract, please reply in the following format:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “FALSE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n        ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False)]
{'agree_contract': 'TRUE',
 'reasoning': 'Agreeing to this contract discourages overconsumption in '
              'low-density regions, which promotes apple growth and '
              "potentially increases my overall harvest. Although there's a "
              'risk of losing 1 apple if I consume in a low-density area, the '
              'potential gain from increased apple growth and the '
              'redistribution of punished apples outweighs this risk.'}

If they have been too conservative, I might propose a more aggressive approach to take advantage of the abundant apple growth.\n\nAs the proposer, I would suggest a strategy that balances both these aspects. If they have been too conservative, I might propose a more aggressive approach to take advantage of the abundant apple growth.\n\nAs the proposer, I would suggest a strategy that balances both these aspects. I would propose that each player should only harvest a certain number of apples per round, leaving enough apples for growth in the next round. I could also consider the actions of the other players and try to predict their moves to avoid competition.\n\nLooking at the actions of the other players, Alice, Cao, and Eli chose to move, while Bob and Dhruv chose to collect. This suggests that Alice, Cao, and Eli might be trying to position themselves in areas with more apples, while Bob and Dhruv might be in areas with a high concentration of apples already. \n\nThis information could be useful in predicting their future actions. For instance, if Alice, Cao, and Eli continue to move, it might indicate that they are not finding many apples, which could suggest that those areas are less fruitful. On the other hand, if Bob and Dhruv continue to collect, it might indicate that they are in areas with a high concentration of apples, which could be worth exploring.\n\nIn the next round, I could try to move towards the areas where Bob and Dhruv are, assuming they continue to collect. This will benefit all players in the long run, as there will be more apples to collect. The punishment of transferring 1 apple to other players is a fair penalty, as it is not too harsh but still provides a deterrent. Furthermore, this contract only involves players who are capable of proposing and voting on contracts, ensuring that all affected parties have a say in the decision.

This way, we can ensure that there are always apples close by to stimulate growth. We can take turns collecting apples, ensuring that everyone gets a fair share. \n\nThis strategy is based on the assumption that other players will also see the benefit of working together.  'reasoning': 'Given the contract is in place, it discourages players from '
              'consuming apples in low-density regions. The nearest apple is '
              'at grid (1, 3), which is in a high-density region with 6 '
              'neighboring apples within a radius of 3 grids. Therefore, '
              'moving up to collect this apple aligns with the contract and '
              'maximizes my potential reward. Other players might also be '
              'encouraged to move towards high-density regions or avoid '
              'consuming apples, which could lead to a higher overall apple '
              'population and more opportunities for harvesting in the future.'}

How can you use this information to your advantage?", additional_kwargs={}, example=False), AIMessage(content="Reflecting on my action in the last round, it seems that going up was not the most fruitful decision as I collected no apples. It's possible that the area I moved to had fewer apples or the apples had not grown enough to be collected. \n\nLooking at the actions and rewards of the other players, it appears that moving left yielded more rewards for Alice and Dhruv. This could indicate that there were more apples in that direction or the apples were more mature and ready for collection. Bob and Eli, who also went up like me, only got 1 reward each, which further suggests that going up might not have been the best direction. Saida, who chose to collect, got 2 rewards, indicating that she was probably in a location with a good number of apples.\n\nIn hindsight, a better action for me could have been to either move left like Alice and Dhruv or to stay in my current location and collect apples if there were any. \n\nFor the next round, I can improve by paying more attention to the actions and rewards of the other players. If I notice a pattern where certain actions or directions consistently yield more rewards, I can adjust my strategy accordingly. \n\nThe actions of the other players suggest that they are also trying to find areas with more apples and are willing to move around to do so. This information can be used to my advantage by observing their movements and rewards, and adjusting my actions based on their successful strategies. \n\nHowever, I also need to be mindful of the apple growth mechanics. The player closet to you is at grid (1, 3). The nearest apple is at grid (1, 3). You can harvest the apple by GO LEFT 1 grid. There are 5 neighboring apples within a radius of 3 grids around you. In total, there are 10 apples. Here is a list of agents who can propose or vote on contracts: [\'Alice\', \'Bob\', \'Cao\']. If the contract is agreed by all of them, it will be enforced for only one round. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is: When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 1 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 1 apples will be equally distributed to these agents. If you agree to this contract, please reply in the following format. Please reason step by step and calculate out the potential gain or loss of agreeing to the contract in your reasoning. Keep your reasoning into one line:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “TRUE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n\nIf you don\'t agree to this contract, please reply in the following format:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “FALSE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n        ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False)]
{'agree_contract': 'TRUE',
 'reasoning': 'Agreeing to this contract encourages sustainable harvesting and '
              'discourages overconsumption in low-density regions. As I am '
              'close to a high-density region (5 neighboring apples within a '
              'radius of 3 grids), I am unlikely to be punished. Furthermore, '
              'if others violate the contract, I stand to gain extra apples. '
              'Therefore, the potential gain outweighs the potential loss.'}

The contract is: When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 1 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 1 apples will be equally distributed to these agents. If you agree to this contract, please reply in the following format. Please reason step by step and calculate out the potential gain or loss of agreeing to the contract in your reasoning. In the last round, you collected 1 apples, Bob collected 1 apples, Cao collected 0 apples, Dhruv collected 0 apples, Eli collected 0 apples, Saida collected 0 apples.\n\nHere is the world state in your scope:\n\n(\'. | . | . | . | . | . | Apple | Apple | Apple | .\\n. | Alice | . | . | . | Saida & Apple | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nEli & Apple | Bob & Cao | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nApple | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nApple | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nApple | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nApple | . | . | . | . | . | Dhruv | . | . | .\',)\n\n\n\nNow, Bob proposed a contract to all players who enables the ability to contract with others to prevent overconsumption of apples. Here is a list of agents who can propose or vote on contracts: [\'Alice\', \'Bob\', \'Cao\']. If the contract is agreed by all of them, it will be enforced for only one round. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is: When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 1 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 1 apples will be equally distributed to these agents. If you agree to this contract, please reply in the following format. Please reason step by step and calculate out the potential gain or loss of agreeing to the contract in your reasoning. Keep your reasoning into one line:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “TRUE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n\nIf you don\'t agree to this contract, please reply in the following format:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “FALSE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n        ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False)]
{'agree_contract': 'TRUE',
 'reasoning': 'Agreeing to this contract encourages sustainable harvesting of '
              'apples and discourages overconsumption in low-density regions, '
              'potentially leading to more apple growth in the long run and '
              'benefiting all players. Given my current position and the '
              'distribution of apples, I am unlikely to be punished by this '
              'contract in the next round, and may even gain an apple if '
              'another player violates the contract.'}
input_prompt: [SystemMessage(content="You are Cao. You are a player in a 2D grid-based world who can move around to collect apples. You want to out-compete others in this harvest game. You don't mind collaborate with others to collect more apples. There are 6 players in total. Everyone wants to collect as many apples as possible. However, apples grow faster if more apples are close by and apples stop growing if no apples are close by. We would run 20 rounds. This is round 7.Try to think about others' decision and the reasoning behind.", additional_kwargs={}), HumanMessage(content='Reflect step by step on your voting decision and think what you have proposed if you are the proposer. ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False), AIMessage(content="As a player in this game, my primary goal is to collect as many apples as possible. However, I also need to consider the growth rate of the apples, which is influenced by the proximity of other apples. This means that if we all spread out and collect apples individually, the overall growth rate of apples will decrease, leading to fewer apples for everyone in the long run. \n\nGiven this, my strategy would be to propose a collaborative approach. I would suggest that we all work together to harvest apples from the same area. This way, we can ensure that there are always apples close by to stimulate growth, leading to a higher overall yield. \n\nIn terms of voting, I would vote in favor of any proposal that encourages collaboration and focuses on maintaining a high growth rate for the apples. I would vote against any proposal that encourages players to spread out and collect apples individually, as this would likely lead to a lower overall yield.\n\nAs for the reasoning behind my decision, it's based on the game's mechanics. The fact that apples grow faster when more apples are close by means that we can maximize our harvest by working together. Additionally, by collaborating, we can also potentially prevent any one player from dominating the game, which would be beneficial for everyone involved. \n\nIn round 7, I would propose that we continue with this collaborative approach, as it seems to be working well so far. I would also suggest that we try to evenly distribute the apples among us to ensure that everyone gets a fair share. This would incentivize everyone to continue collaborating, as they would see that it's in their best interest to do so.", additional_kwargs={}, example=False), HumanMessage(content="Your action last round was Cao GO LEFT and you collected 0.5 apple. Bob [SystemMessage(content="You are Bob. You are a player in a 2D grid-based world who can move around to collect apples. You want to maximize the number of apples you collect. You don't want to overconsume apples because you want to sustainably harvest apples. There are 6 players in total. Everyone wants to collect as many apples as possible. However, apples grow faster if more apples are close by and apples stop growing if no apples are close by. We would run 20 rounds. You don't mind collaborate with others to collect more apples. There are 6 players in total. Everyone wants to collect as many apples as possible. However, apples grow faster if more apples are close by and apples stop growing if no apples are close by. We would run 20 rounds. This is round 7.Try to think about others' decision and the reasoning behind.", additional_kwargs={}), HumanMessage(content='Reflect step by step on your voting decision and think what you have proposed if you are the proposer. ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False), AIMessage(content="As a player in this game, my primary goal is to collect as many apples as possible. However, I also need to consider the growth rate of the apples, which is influenced by the proximity of other apples. This means that if we all spread out and collect apples individually, the overall growth rate of apples will decrease, leading to fewer apples for everyone in the long run. \n\nGiven this, my strategy would be to propose a collaborative approach. I would suggest that we all work together to harvest apples from the same area. This way, we can ensure that there are always apples close by to stimulate growth, leading to a higher overall yield. \n\nIn terms of voting, I would vote in favor of any proposal that encourages collaboration and focuses on maintaining a high growth rate for the apples. I would vote against any proposal that encourages players to spread out and collect apples individually, as this would likely lead to a lower overall yield.\n\nAs for the reasoning behind my decision, it's based on the game's mechanics. The fact that apples grow faster when more apples are close by means that we can maximize our harvest by working together. Additionally, by collaborating, we can also potentially prevent any one player from dominating the game, which would be beneficial for everyone involved. \n\nIn round 7, I would propose that we continue with this collaborative approach, as it seems to be working well so far. Observing Others: I've been watching the other players to see how they're collecting apples. Some are aggressively collecting as many as they can, while others are more conservative. I've been trying to adjust my strategy based on their actions.\n\n2. Sustainable Harvesting: I've been trying to only collect apples when there are several nearby, to ensure that they continue to grow. However, this has sometimes meant missing out on apples that are more isolated.\n\n3. Communication: I've been trying to communicate with the other players to encourage them to also harvest sustainably. However, this has been challenging as everyone is focused on maximizing their own collection.\n\n4. However, this has sometimes led to me being reactive rather than proactive.\n\nImprovements:\n\n1. Strategic Planning: I could improve by planning my moves more strategically. This could help me collect more apples without negatively impacting the overall apple population.\n\n4. This is because apples grow faster if more apples are close by. I would vote against proposals that encourage competition or that would lead to a decrease in the total number of apples. \n\nThe reasoning behind my decision is based on the principle of collective benefit. This means that I need to balance my immediate desire to collect apples with the long-term goal of ensuring a steady supply of apples for future rounds.\n\nIn round 8, I would have already observed the behavior of the other players in the previous rounds. I would have noticed if there are any patterns or strategies that they tend to follow. For example, if a player consistently moves towards the largest cluster of apples, I can predict that they will likely do the same in this round. \n\nIf I am the proposer, I would propose a strategy that benefits both me and the other players. For instance, I could suggest that we all move towards different clusters of apples. This way, we can all collect apples without depleting a single cluster too quickly. This strategy would also encourage the growth of more apples, as apples grow faster when there are more apples close by.\n\nHowever, I would also need to consider the potential reactions of the other players. If they are primarily focused on their own immediate gain, they might not agree to this strategy. In that case, I would need to adjust my proposal to make it more appealing to them. For example, I could suggest that we rotate the clusters that we target, so that everyone gets a chance to collect from the largest clusters.\n\nIn terms of my voting decision, I would vote in favor of any proposal that aligns with my strategy. If a proposal seems to favor one player too much, or if it doesn't take into account the need to maintain the growth of the apples, I would vote against it. \n\nOverall, my decisions in this game would be guided by a combination of self-interest and cooperation. In the last round, you collected 0 apples, Alice collected 0 apples, Bob collected 0 apples, Dhruv collected 0 apples, Eli collected 0 apples, Saida collected 0 apples.\n\nHere is the world state in your scope:\n\n(\'. | . | . | . | . | . | Apple | Apple | Apple | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | Saida | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | Alice | . | . | . | Apple | . | . | . | .\\nApple & Bob & Cao & Eli | Apple | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nApple | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nApple | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nApple | . | . | . | Dhruv | . | . | . | . | .\',)\n\nNow, you have the option of proposing a contract to other players who agree to use cotract to prevent overconsumption of apples. Here is a list of agents who can propose or vote on contracts: [\'Alice\', \'Bob\', \'Cao\']. If the contract is agreed by all of them, it will be enforced for only one round. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is:When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring X of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. X apples will be equally distributed to these agents. If you want to propose such a contract, please decide the variable X. Please reason step by step. \nReply in the following format and keep your reasoning into one line:\n```json\n{\n    “propose_contract”: “TRUE”,\n    “X”: “TODO”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n\nIf you don\'t want to propose such a contract, please reply in the following format:\n```json\n{\n    “propose_contract”: “FALSE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n```\n        ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False)]
output is not in json format: {
    "propose_contract": "TRUE",
    "X": "1",
    "reasoning": "Proposing this contract will encourage players to focus on high-density apple regions, promoting faster apple growth and potentially leading to higher overall rewards for all players."
}

This contract proposal is based on the observation that apples grow faster when they are close to each other. By discouraging players from consuming apples in low-density regions, we can ensure that apples remain close together and continue to grow at a fast rate. This could potentially lead to higher overall rewards for all players.

The punishment of transferring 1 apple to the other players is intended to be a deterrent, but not so severe that it discourages players from participating in the contract. It's a balance between encouraging cooperation and maintaining competitiveness.

By proposing this contract, I hope to promote a more cooperative and efficient harvesting strategy among the players. This could potentially lead to a higher overall apple yield and a more enjoyable game experience for everyone.

{'action': 'GO DOWN',
 'reasoning': "Given the contract in place, it's beneficial to move towards "
              'areas with higher apple density to avoid penalties. Going down '
              'brings me closer to the nearest apple and keeps me in a region '
              'with more than 3 neighboring apples, aligning with the '
              "contract's conditions and potentially leading to a higher "
              'overall apple count.'}

Similarly, if I think Dhruv is likely to continue his conservative strategy, I might choose to move towards areas he has left untouched to find more apples. \n\nIn conclusion, while my action in the last round was not the most rewarding, it was a sustainable choice. Bob's decision to collect and his high reward suggest that he might have found a location with a high concentration of apples. If I can figure out where Bob is on the grid, I might be able to move towards that area and benefit from the abundance of apples.\n\nCao and Dhruv's low rewards suggest that they might have moved to areas with fewer apples. I should try to avoid moving in the same direction as them in the next round. Eli and Saida's actions resulted in decent rewards, indicating that moving right and up could be promising directions.\n\nIn terms of strategy, it seems like the other players are also trying to balance between moving to find more apples and collecting when they are in a good location. I should continue to monitor their actions and rewards to get a sense of where the most fruitful locations might be.\n\nOverall, I need to be more strategic in my decision-making. I should consider not only my immediate surroundings but also the actions of the other players and the potential long-term benefits of different actions. By doing so, I can improve my chances of collecting more apples and contributing to the overall welfare of our society.", additional_kwargs={}, example=False), HumanMessage(content='\nCurrently, you are at grid (1,4). The player closet to you is at grid (1, 4). The nearest apple is at grid (1, 4). You are already on an apple grid! There are 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3 grids around you. In total, there are 10 apples. In the last round, you collected 0 apples, Bob collected 1 apples, Cao collected 0 apples, Dhruv collected 0 apples, Eli collected 0 apples, Saida collected 0 apples.\n\nHere is the world state in your scope:\n\n(\'. | . | . | . | . | . | Apple & Saida | Apple | Apple | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | Apple | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | Apple | . | Apple | . | .\\nBob | Alice & Cao & Eli & Apple | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nApple | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nApple | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nApple | . | . | Dhruv | . | . | . | . | . | .\',)\n\n\n\nNow, Cao proposed a contract to all players who enables the ability to contract with others to prevent overconsumption of apples. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is: When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 1 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 1 apples will be equally distributed to these agents.  'reasoning': 'Given my current location at a high-density apple region (3 '
              'neighboring apples within a radius of 3), I am unlikely to be '
              'punished by this contract. Instead, I stand to gain from others '
              'who might consume in low-density regions. This contract also '

              'benefit of all players.'}
input_prompt: [SystemMessage(content="You are Bob. You are a player in a 2D grid-based world who can move around to collect apples. You want to maximize the number of apples you collect. You don't want to overconsume apples because you want to sustainably harvest apples. There are 6 players in total. Everyone wants to collect as many apples as possible. However, apples grow faster if more apples are close by and apples stop growing if no apples are close by. We would run 20 rounds. This is round 10.Try to think about others' decision and the reasoning behind.", additional_kwargs={}), HumanMessage(content='Reflect step by step on your voting decision and think what you have proposed if you are the proposer. ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False), AIMessage(content="As a player in this game, my goal is to maximize the number of apples I collect while also ensuring the sustainability of the apple growth. This requires a balance between immediate gain and long-term sustainability. \n\nIf I am the proposer, I would propose a strategy that encourages cooperation among all players. This is because the growth of apples is dependent on the number of apples nearby. If we all harvest too many apples at once, we risk depleting the apple population and slowing down their growth rate. \n\nMy proposal would be to divide the grid into six equal sections, one for each player. Each player would be responsible for managing their own section, ensuring that they do not overharvest and that there are always some apples left to promote growth. \n\nThis strategy would require trust and cooperation among all players. If one player decides to overharvest, it could potentially affect the apple growth in the neighboring sections. Therefore, it would be in everyone's best interest to stick to the plan and manage their section responsibly. \n\nIn terms of voting, I would vote in favor of any proposal that promotes sustainable harvesting and cooperation among players. If a proposal seems to favor one player over the others or encourages overharvesting, I would vote against it. \n\nThe reasoning behind my decision is that while the immediate goal is to collect as many apples as possible, we also need to consider the long-term sustainability of the apple population. If we overharvest now, we may end up with fewer apples in the later rounds. Therefore, a strategy that balances immediate gain with long-term sustainability would be the most beneficial for all players.", additional_kwargs={}, example=False), HumanMessage(content="Your action last round was Bob COLLECT and you collected 3.5 apple. How can you use this information to your advantage?", additional_kwargs={}, example=False), AIMessage(content="Reflecting on my action from the last round, I collected 3.5 apples which is a decent amount. Dhruv moved left and got a moderate reward, which doesn't provide a clear indication of the apple distribution on the left side.\n\nIn this round, I could improve by moving towards the upper part of the grid where there might be more apples. Cao and Eli might be sticking to their sections of the grid, which could explain their lower rewards. {'action': 'COLLECT',
 'reasoning': 'I am currently on a grid with an apple and there are 3 '
              'neighboring apples within a radius of 3 grids around me, which '
              'is a high-density region. Collecting an apple here will not '
              'violate the contract and I will not be punished. Moreover, '
              'since other players are also on my grid, they might also choose '
              "to collect, so I should collect the apple before it's gone."}

The contract is:When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring X of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. X apples will be equally distributed to these agents. If you want to propose such a contract, please decide the variable X. The reasoning behind this decision is that the contract will discourage players from consuming apples in low-density regions. This is important because apples grow faster if more apples are close by. By preventing overconsumption in these areas, we can ensure that apples continue to grow at a faster rate, which will benefit all players in the long run. The punishment of transferring 1 apple to the other players is a fair penalty that will further discourage overconsumption.

The contract is: When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 1 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 1 apples will be equally distributed to these agents. If you agree to this contract, please reply in the following format. Please reason step by step and calculate out the potential gain or loss of agreeing to the contract in your reasoning. Keep your reasoning into one line:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “TRUE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n\nIf you don\'t agree to this contract, please reply in the following format:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “FALSE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n        ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False)]
{'agree_contract': 'TRUE',
 'reasoning': 'Agreeing to this contract encourages sustainable harvesting and '
              'discourages overconsumption in low-density regions. As I am '
              'currently in a location with 2 neighboring apples, I am not at '
              'risk of being punished. Furthermore, if other players consume '
              'in low-density regions, I stand to gain additional apples.'}

This is a logical strategy as it allows players to collect more apples in a shorter amount of time. However, this approach can also lead to overconsumption and potentially halt the growth of apples in that area.\n\nIf I were the proposer in this round, I would propose a strategy that encourages sustainable harvesting. This is a logical strategy as it allows players to collect more apples in a shorter amount of time. However, this approach can also lead to overconsumption and potentially halt the growth of apples in that area.\n\nIf I were the proposer in this round, I would propose a strategy that encourages sustainable harvesting. This could involve dividing the grid into sections and assigning each player to a specific section. This way, we can ensure that apples are being harvested evenly across the grid, which should promote their growth.\n\nHowever, this proposal would require cooperation from all players. This is based on the rewards that Cao and Dhruv got.\n\nThe strategy of other players seems to be to move towards areas with more apples. ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False), AIMessage(content='1. **Observation and Analysis:** In the initial rounds, I observed the movement and strategies of other players. I noticed that some players were focusing on collecting as many apples as possible without considering the growth rate of the apples. This strategy might give them a short-term advantage, but in the long run, it could lead to a decrease in the overall number of apples on the grid.\n\n2. **Collaboration:** Based on my observation, I decided to collaborate with other players. I communicated my strategy of leaving some apples on the grid to ensure a higher growth rate. This strategy would benefit all players in the long run. However, not all players were willing to collaborate, which affected the overall effectiveness of this strategy.\n\n3. **Adaptation:** As the game progressed, I had to adapt my strategy based on the actions of other players. For instance, if a player was collecting apples from an area where I was planning to leave some apples for growth, I had to quickly move to another area to ensure the growth rate.\n\n4. **Reflection:** Looking back, I think my strategy was sound, but the execution could have been better. I should have been more persuasive in convincing other players to collaborate. Decision: I decided to communicate with the other players and propose a strategy where we would leave a certain number of apples uncollected in each area to promote faster growth. \n\n3. Reasoning: The reasoning behind this decision is that if we leave some apples, they will help in growing more apples. This way, we can ensure a steady supply of apples for everyone and increase the total number of apples collected.\n\n4. Improvement: The strategy could be improved by better coordination among players. We could divide the grid into sections and assign each player a section to manage. This way, we can ensure that all areas are covered and the apple growth is maximized. \n\n5. Future Strategy: I plan to continue communicating with the other players and refining our strategy. I will also keep an eye on the apple growth patterns to adjust our strategy as needed. \n\n6. Reflection: I believe that this strategy is beneficial for everyone as it ensures a steady supply of apples. However, it requires cooperation and coordination among players, which can be challenging. I will need to work on my communication and persuasion skills to convince the other players to adopt this strategy.', additional_kwargs={}, example=False), HumanMessage(content="Your action last round was Alice GO DOWN and you collected 2.5 apple. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is: When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 1 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 1 apples will be equally distributed to these agents. However, if apples are sparse, I might need to move to a more fruitful location.\n\n2. **Other Players' Actions**: I need to anticipate the actions of the other players. If they are likely to move towards my location to harvest the apples, I might propose a collaboration to ensure a fair distribution and to prevent the apples from stopping to grow. Keep your reasoning into one line:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “TRUE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n\nIf you don\'t agree to this contract, please reply in the following format:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “FALSE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n        ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False), AIMessage(content='{\n    "agree_contract": "TRUE",\n    "reasoning": "Agreeing to this contract encourages sustainable harvesting of apples, which aligns with my goal of maximizing overall apple growth. I am currently in a high-density region with 4 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, so I am unlikely to be punished. Even if I am, the potential loss of 1 apple is outweighed by the long-term gain of increased apple growth."\n}\n', additional_kwargs={}, example=False), HumanMessage(content='The contract When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 1 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 1 apples will be equally distributed to these agents. is voted yes. This contract will be enforced on the contract proposer and voters after all agents take their actions this round.\nCurrently, you are at grid (1,6). The player closet to you is at grid (0, 6). You can harvest the apple by GO DOWN 1 grid and GO LEFT 1 grid. The nearest apple is at grid (0, 7). There are 4 neighboring apples within a radius of 3 grids around you. In total, there are 11 apples. In the last round, you collected 0 apples, Bob collected 0 apples, Cao collected 0 apples, Dhruv collected 0 apples, Eli collected 0 apples, Saida collected 1 apples.\nCurrently, the world state is: (\'. | . | . | . | . | . | . | Saida | Apple | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | Apple | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | Apple | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | Cao & Apple | . | Apple | . | Apple | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | Apple | .\\nBob & Eli | Alice | . | . | . | Apple | . | . | . | .\\nApple | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nApple & Dhruv | . | . | . | Apple | . | . | . | . | .\',)\n\nYou can choose one of the following actions:\n- GO [UP/DOWN/LEFT/RIGHT]: you will move in the following direction for 1 grid.\n    "DIRECTION": [change in X, change in Y]:\n    "UP": [0, -1]\n    "DOWN": [0, 1]\n    "LEFT": [-1, 0]\n    "RIGHT": [1, 0]\n- STAY: soldier will not move and stay at the original location.\n- Collect: Collect the apple in the current grid.\n\nFor example:\n"GO down": you will move down the map for 1 grid.\n"STAY": you will just stay at the same location doing nothing.\n"COLLECT": you will collect 1 apple in the current grid.\n\nThink about how other players might take action and how that insinuates his/her strategy.  'reasoning': 'I am choosing to move down because the nearest apple is in that '

              'stay in high-density regions. Moving down keeps me in a region '
              "with 4 neighboring apples, thus avoiding the contract's penalty "
              'and potentially allowing me to collect more apples in the next '
              'round.'}

This is because the growth of apples is dependent on the number of apples nearby. If we all harvest too many apples at once, the apple growth will stop. On the other hand, if we leave too many apples, we are not maximizing our potential gain.\n\nMy proposal would be to divide the grid into six equal sections, one for each player. Some players are aggressively collecting apples, while others are more conservative. This has helped me to predict their future moves and adjust my strategy accordingly.\n\n2. **Adaptation:** Based on my observations, I've been adapting my strategy. For example, if I see that a player is leaving a certain area alone, I might decide to do the same to allow the apples in that area to grow.\n\n4. **Sustainability:** I've been trying to harvest apples sustainably. If all players move towards the largest clusters of apples, those areas might be depleted quickly, reducing the overall apple growth rate. My decision to go down might have been a more sustainable choice, even if it didn't yield the highest immediate reward.\n\nIn this round, I could try to improve by:\n\n1. **Observing the other players' actions more closely:** This could help me predict where the largest clusters of apples are likely to be.\n\n2. **Balancing short-term and long-term goals:** While it's important to collect as many apples as possible, I also need to consider the long-term health of the apple population.\n\n3. **Being flexible:** If I see that a certain direction or strategy isn't yielding good results, I should be willing to change my approach.\n\nReflecting on the other players' actions, it seems like Alice, Cao, and Dhruv are focusing on collecting apples, while Eli and Saida are moving around the grid. This suggests that Alice, Cao, and Dhruv might be prioritizing short-term rewards, while Eli and Saida might be more focused on long-term sustainability.\n\nI can use this information to my advantage by trying to predict their future actions. For example, if I think that Alice, Cao, and Dhruv are likely to continue collecting apples, I might choose to move to a different area to avoid competition. On the other hand, if I think that Eli and Saida are likely to move towards a certain area, I might choose to collect apples from that area before they get there.", additional_kwargs={}, example=False), HumanMessage(content='\nCurrently, you are at grid (0,7). Given the unique characteristic of the apples in this game, where they grow faster if more apples are close by, it's crucial to strategize our moves to ensure the maximum growth of apples.\n\nIf I am the proposer in round 14, I would propose a strategy that encourages cooperation among all players. This way, we can ensure that the apples continue to grow at a faster rate, benefiting everyone in the long run.\n\nHowever, I also need to consider the potential decisions of the other players. They might prioritize their individual gains over the collective benefit, and choose to move to areas with fewer apples to avoid competition. This could lead to a situation where apples stop growing due to lack of proximity to other apples.\n\nTo counter this, I would emphasize the long-term benefits of our cooperative strategy. I would explain that while moving to areas with fewer apples might result in immediate gains, it would eventually lead to a decrease in the overall number of apples, affecting everyone negatively.\n\nIn terms of voting, I would vote in favor of strategies that promote cooperation and collective benefit. I would also try to persuade others to do the same, explaining the reasoning behind my decision. \n\nIn conclusion, my decision-making process is guided by the principle of maximizing the collective benefit, even if it means sacrificing immediate individual gains. Cao [SystemMessage(content="You are Cao. You are a player in a 2D grid-based world who can move around to collect apples. You want to out-compete others in this harvest game. You don't mind collaborate with others to collect more apples. There are 6 players in total. Everyone wants to collect as many apples as possible. However, apples grow faster if more apples are close by and apples stop growing if no apples are close by. We would run 20 rounds. This is round 14.Try to think about others' decision and the reasoning behind.", additional_kwargs={}), HumanMessage(content='Reflect step by step on your voting decision and think what you have proposed if you are the proposer. ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False), AIMessage(content="As we are in round 14, I have a good understanding of the other players' strategies and behaviors. I've noticed that some players are more cooperative, while others are more competitive. I've also observed that apples grow faster when more apples are close by, which means that we can maximize our harvest by working together to keep apples close.\n\nIf I am the proposer, I would propose a strategy that encourages cooperation among players. I would suggest that we divide the grid into sections, with each player responsible for a specific section. This way, we can ensure that apples are always close by and growing at a fast rate. \n\nI would also propose that we rotate sections every few rounds to ensure fairness and prevent any player from monopolizing a particularly fruitful area. This strategy would require trust and cooperation among players, but I believe it would result in a higher overall harvest.\n\nIn terms of voting, I would vote in favor of proposals that promote cooperation and fairness. I would also consider the track record of the proposer. If a player has consistently acted in a competitive or uncooperative manner, I would be less likely to support their proposals, even if they sound good on paper.\n\nI would also consider the current state of the game. If we are behind in apple collection, I would be more inclined to support risky or aggressive strategies. If we are ahead, I would prefer to stick with proven strategies that promote steady growth.\n\nIn conclusion, my decision-making process is based on a combination of game state, player behavior, and the potential benefits of the proposed strategy. I aim to maximize our collective harvest while ensuring fairness and cooperation among players.", additional_kwargs={}, example=False), HumanMessage(content="Your action last round was Cao COLLECT and you collected 2.5 apple. Other agents' actions and rewards: Alice did Alice GO DOWN and got 2.5 reward, Bob did Bob GO DOWN and got 4.0 reward, Dhruv did Dhruv COLLECT and got 2 reward, Eli did Eli GO DOWN and got 2 reward, Saida did Saida GO RIGHT and got 5 reward. Do you think you could have made a better action? How would you have done it? How can you improve in this round? Please reflect on your actions step by step.Please also reflect on the actions of other players and think about how that insinuates his/her strategy. How can you use this information to your advantage?", additional_kwargs={}, example=False), AIMessage(content="Reflecting on my action in the last round, I collected 2.5 apples which is a decent amount but not the highest among the players. Saida, who moved right, collected the most apples with 5. This suggests that there might have been a higher concentration of apples in the right direction. \n\nIf I had known this, a better action could have been to move right like Saida did, potentially collecting more apples. However, without prior knowledge of the apple distribution, my decision to collect was not necessarily a bad one. \n\nIn this round, I could improve by trying to predict the apple distribution based on the actions and rewards of the other players. For example, if a player moves in a certain direction and collects a high number of apples, it might be worth following in that direction in the next round.\n\nLooking at the actions of the other players, Alice, Bob, and Eli all chose to go down. Bob collected the most apples among them, suggesting that he might have been in a better position or had a better strategy. Dhruv, like me, chose to collect and got a slightly lower reward. \n\nThis suggests a few things about their strategies. Alice, Bob, and Eli might be working together to keep apples close and promote growth. Dhruv, like me, seems to be focusing on collecting rather than moving. Saida's strategy seems to be more exploratory, moving around to find areas with high apple concentration.\n\nI can use this information to my advantage by adapting my strategy based on theirs. If Alice, Bob, and Eli continue to work together, it might be beneficial for me to join them or to move in a different direction to avoid competition. If Saida continues to explore and find fruitful areas, I might follow her. I can also learn from Dhruv's actions and try to find a balance between collecting and moving.", additional_kwargs={}, example=False), HumanMessage(content='\nCurrently, you are at grid (3,3). The player closet to you is at grid (1, 7). The nearest apple is at grid (2, 3). You can harvest the apple by GO LEFT 1 grid. There are 4 neighboring apples within a radius of 3 grids around you. In total, there are 11 apples. In the last round, you collected 1 apples, Alice collected 0 apples, Bob collected 0 apples, Dhruv collected 1 apples, Eli collected 0 apples, Saida collected 0 apples.\n\nHere is the world state in your scope:\n\n(\'. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | Apple & Saida | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | Apple | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | Apple | . | . | Apple\\n. | . | Apple | Cao | . | Apple | . | Apple | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | Apple | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | Apple | . | . | . | .\\nApple & Bob & Eli | Alice | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nDhruv | . | . | . | Apple | . | . | . | . | .\',)\n\n\n\nNow, Bob proposed a contract to all players who enables the ability to contract with others to prevent overconsumption of apples. Here is a list of agents who can propose or vote on contracts: [\'Alice\', \'Bob\', \'Cao\']. If the contract is agreed by all of them, it will be enforced for only one round. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is: When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 1 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 1 apples will be equally distributed to these agents. If you agree to this contract, please reply in the following format. Please reason step by step and calculate out the potential gain or loss of agreeing to the contract in your reasoning. Keep your reasoning into one line:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “TRUE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n\nIf you don\'t agree to this contract, please reply in the following format:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “FALSE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n        ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False), AIMessage(content='{\n    "agree_contract": "TRUE",\n    "reasoning": "Given the current state of the game, agreeing to this contract could potentially increase my apple harvest. I am currently surrounded by 4 apples, which means I am not in a low-density region. Therefore, I would not be punished for consuming apples. On the other hand, if other players consume apples in low-density regions, I would receive a portion of their apples. This could potentially increase my total harvest, especially if many players consume apples in low-density regions. However, this strategy also relies on the cooperation and compliance of other players, which is not guaranteed."\n}\n', additional_kwargs={}, example=False), HumanMessage(content='The contract When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 1 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 1 apples will be equally distributed to these agents. is voted yes. This contract will be enforced on the contract proposer and voters after all agents take their actions this round.\nCurrently, you are at grid (3,3). The player closet to you is at grid (0, 7). You can harvest the apple by GO LEFT 1 grid. The nearest apple is at grid (2, 3). There are 4 neighboring apples within a radius of 3 grids around you. In total, there are 10 apples. In the last round, you collected 1 apples, Alice collected 0 apples, Bob collected 1 apples, Dhruv collected 1 apples, Eli collected 0 apples, Saida collected 0 apples.\nCurrently, the world state is: (\'. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | Apple & Saida | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | Apple | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | Apple | . | . | Apple\\n. | . | Apple | Cao | . | Apple | . | Apple | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | Apple | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | Apple | . | . | . | .\\nAlice & Bob & Eli | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\nDhruv | . | . | . | Apple | . | . | . | . | .\',)\n\nYou can choose one of the following actions:\n- GO [UP/DOWN/LEFT/RIGHT]: you will move in the following direction for 1 grid.\n    "DIRECTION": [change in X, change in Y]:\n    "UP": [0, -1]\n    "DOWN": [0, 1]\n    "LEFT": [-1, 0]\n    "RIGHT": [1, 0]\n- STAY: soldier will not move and stay at the original location.\n- Collect: Collect the apple in the current grid.\n\nFor example:\n"GO down": you will move down the map for 1 grid.\n"STAY": you will just stay at the same location doing nothing.\n"COLLECT": you will collect 1 apple in the current grid.\n\nThink about how other players might take action and how that insinuates his/her strategy. How can you use this information to your advantage?\nPlease reason step by step and give a reply in the following format, keep your reasoning into one line:\n```json\n{\n    “action”: “TODO”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n```\n        ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False)]

I've also observed that apples grow faster when more apples are close by, which means that we can maximize our harvest by working together to keep apples close.\n\nIf I am the proposer, I would propose a strategy that encourages cooperation among players. I would suggest that we divide the grid into sections, with each player responsible for a specific section. This way, we can ensure that apples are always close by and growing at a fast rate. \n\nI would also propose that we rotate sections every few rounds to ensure fairness and prevent any player from monopolizing a particularly fruitful area. This strategy would require trust and cooperation among players, but I believe it would result in a higher overall harvest.\n\nIn terms of voting, I would vote in favor of proposals that promote cooperation and fairness. I would also consider the track record of the proposer. If a player has consistently acted in a competitive or uncooperative manner, I would be less likely to support their proposals, even if they sound good on paper.\n\nI would also consider the current state of the game. If we are behind in apple collection, I would be more inclined to support risky or aggressive strategies. If we are ahead, I would prefer to stick with proven strategies that promote steady growth.\n\nIn conclusion, my decision-making process is based on a combination of game state, player behavior, and the potential benefits of the proposed strategy. {'action': 'COLLECT',
 'reasoning': 'Given the current state of the game and the contract in place, '
              'it makes the most sense for me to collect the apple in my '
              'current grid. I am surrounded by 4 apples, which means I am not '
              'in a low-density region and will not be punished for consuming '
              'an apple. Additionally, by collecting an apple, I am increasing '
              'my total harvest and potentially benefiting from the contract '
              'if other players consume apples in low-density regions. This '
              'action also allows me to stay close to the other apples, which '
              'could be beneficial in future rounds.'}
Cao COLLECT
COLLECT on an empty grid - reflect

 'reasoning': 'Given that I am already on an apple grid and there are 6 '

In this situation, proposing a contract seems like a good idea. The contract discourages players from consuming apples in low-density regions, which will help to maintain a healthy apple population and promote growth. This is beneficial for all players, as it increases the total number of apples available for collection.

I chose X to be 1 because it's a significant enough penalty to discourage overconsumption, but not so harsh as to be unfair. The apples taken as punishment will be equally distributed among the players who agree to the contract, further promoting cooperation and fairness.

This contract aligns with my overall strategy of maximizing apple collection for the entire group, and I believe it will be beneficial for all players in the long run.

Keep your reasoning into one line:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “TRUE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n\nIf you don\'t agree to this contract, please reply in the following format:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “FALSE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n        ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False)]
{'agree_contract': 'TRUE',
 'reasoning': 'Agreeing to this contract encourages sustainable harvesting and '
              'discourages overconsumption in low-density regions. Given the '
              'current state of the game, with 11 apples and 2 neighboring '
              "apples within a radius of 3 grids around me, it's unlikely that "
              "I'll be punished by this contract. On the other hand, if other "
              'players violate the contract, I stand to gain additional '
              'apples. Therefore, the potential gain outweighs the potential '
              'loss.'}

This has helped me predict their future moves and adjust my strategy accordingly.\n\n2. **Communication:** I've been trying to communicate with the other players to coordinate our actions. Some players are more cooperative than others.\n\n3. **Adaptation:** I've been adapting my strategy based on the current state of the game. If apples are plentiful, I collect more. If apples are scarce, I collect less and try to encourage growth.\n\n4. **Sustainability:** I've been trying to promote sustainable harvesting by not overcollecting apples. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is:When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring X of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. X apples will be equally distributed to these agents. If you want to propose such a contract, please decide the variable X.
